Title:
Evaluation of matrix-assisted laser desorption
ionization-time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) for
identification and clustering of Neisseria gonorrhoeae
Keywords: Neisseria gonorrhoeae, MALDI-TOF MS, G1407, typing
Abstract:
Background: The sexually transmitted infection gonorrhea
remains a public health concern for increasingly becoming resistant to
available drug treatments. The aim of this study was to assess the
usefulness of the matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization-time of
flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) to identify and cluster
Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Methods: From a current surveillance in Italy as
part of the European Gonococcal Antimicrobial Surveillance Programme
(EURO-GASP), 93 gonococci collected from 2007 to 2012 susceptible and
resistant to cefixime have been selected for the study. Minimum
Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) values for cefixime was assessed by Etest
carried out in agreement with the manufacturerâs instructions and
interpreted referring to European Committee on Antimicrobial
Susceptibility testing (EUCAST) clinical breakpoints criteria. Data
obtained by N. gonorrhoeae multiantigen sequence typing (NG-MAST) and
the dendrogram based on the concatenation of porB and tbpB genes were
evaluated. MALDI-TOF MS, to reconfirm gonorrhea identification, analyzed
single colonies from freshly grown isolates and directly applied on a
ground-steel MALDI target plate. For the MALDI-TOF dendrogram cluster
analysis, MSPs (Main Spectrum Profile) from each isolate were created
acquiring 5,000 shots from 10 technical replicates obtained from
bacteria extraction. Results: Cefixime MIC values for 93 gonococci were
as follows: 49 isolates resistant (MIC>0.125 mg/L), 44 susceptible
(MIC range 0.016-0.125 mg/L). Molecular typing by NG-MAST showed 28
sequence types (STs); G1407 was the predominant accounting for 75
gonococci. All the 93 gonococci, except one, were correctly identified
at species level by MALDI-TOF MS and G1407 isolates were divided into
two clusters. Conclusion: MALDI-TOF MS for a real-time detection and
cluster analysis of gonorrhea is a promising tool for surveillance
purposes . Moreover, additional studies are required to collect more
data on the performance of MALDI-TOF MS for gonococci.
